Overview [Power Drills]
Overview [Drill Bits]
Drill Bit Types
Nail Loading
Sanding pad vibrates in a randomly changing circular motion.
Belt rotates around two pulleys; sander is moved while wood is held stationary.
Work is secured and drill moved by hand.
Can be used to drive screw with special bits.
The blade reciprocates up and down, cutting on the up stroke.
The blade reciprocates in and out, cutting on the in stroke.
Wood is held in place while blade is moved.
Wood is moved on table into blade.
Wood is moved on table into blade.
The blade reciprocates up and down, cutting on the down stroke.
Wood is moved across tabletop either against fence or pushed with miter gauge: NEVER CUT FREEHAND.
Blade slides forward on rail, cutting on the pull stroke.
Wood is held in place while blade is moved.
Slides forward above wood.
Swings down in chopping motion.
Slides back on rails, cutting on the push stroke.
Rail assembly can be locked so that saw can only chop like a standard miter saw.
Wood is held in place while blade is moved.
Blade swings down in chopping motion.
Wood is held in place while blade is moved.
The jointer is used to true the edges of boards that is make them very straight at a constant angle to the face.
The wood is pushed on the table along the fence and into the spinning knives.
Planer is used make the faces of a board flat and parallel.
The wood is fed between the spinning roller/knife assembly and the table.
The lathe is used to “turn” or cut rectangular pieces into cylindrical forms.
The wood is mounted between the spindles and spun, while turning chisels are used to cut the cylindrical profiles.
The shaper or router is used to “mold” the edges of boards, that is shape them into specific molding profiles.
The wood is pushed on the table along the fence or with the miter gauge and into the spinning knives.
Uses different bits for many different grinding purposes.
Use for finish sanding on wood, plastic, foam, etc..
Used only to fasten wood together.
Used only to fasten wood together.
Rough sands and shapes.
The spindle spins (and on some models oscillate up and down) while the wood is moved against the tabletop.
Use down draft table for any sanding, routing, or grinding.
Drill bit is mounted in a chuck, which travels up and down on the quill.
Drills holes perpendicular to table.
Bores a squared hole.
The router is used to cut slots and dados, and to mould the edges of boards.
The wood is secured and the router is moved by hand.
Half Sheet Finish Sander: uses a half sheet of sandpaper.
Quarter Sheet Palm Sander: uses a quarter sheet of sandpaper.
Palm Sander: round pad.
Small, hand held belt.
Hand-held drill.
Hand-held, with a short stout blade extending from bottom (foot).
Hand-held, with a stout blade extending from end.
Hand-held circular blade.
Long, continuous band blade looped around large upper and lower wheels
Long, continuous band blade looped around large upper and lower wheels.
A short thin blade held through the table by a long arm.
Circular blade mounted into table.
Circular blade mounted on overhead rail (arm).
Circular blade mounted on a double action arm.
Circular blade mounted on single action arm.
A series of short knives mounted on a horizontal spindle set into a long flat table equipped with a fence.
A series of 15 inch knives mounted on a horizontal spindle set above a short table and equipped with self-feeding rollers.
two spindles equipped with a parallel tool rest
A series of short knives mounted on a vertical spindle set into a short flat table equipped with a fence and miter gauge.
Or a Router mounted upside-down in a table with a fence.
Hand-held rotary grinder.
Five inch pneumatic sander with dust collector.
Pneumatic 18 or 16 gage.
Pneumatic chip nailer.
Combination: belt and disk sander.
A cylindrical sanding spindle mounted in a table.
Self-contained dust collection unit.
Overhead drill mounted above adjustable table.
Hollow square chisel with a drill bit in the center built in a press.
Essentially a smaller, hand held, inverted version of the wood shaper.
